text: Zach Hill face tack hello my needle
drops Anthony Fantana here intranets
busiest music nerd thank you for
watching thank you for subscribing and
thank you guys for suggesting this in
the comments of yesterday's video as
many of you all may know I made this
announcement a couple videos ago I
killed the mod box and now if you want
to make suggestions for future album
reviews do them in the comments of my
most recent video so let's get into this
thing if you know anything about the
best and brightest of modern drumming
then you know Zach Hill hearing Zach
play drums for the first time can be a
serious shock to the system especially
if your introduction to his work is on
one of his many albums with hella
but even though hella is pretty much
where Zach made a name for himself he
has stretched far beyond that band since
its inception if you follow independent
music if you follow underground music
it's nearly impossible to avoid the guy
he's like that dude at a party who's
just talking to everybody the guys
worked with a lot of artists and the
ones that I'm familiar with our Marnie
Stern Mick Barr he's also worked with
waves he's got a nice little
collaboration with Tara mellows by the
name of bygones and on Zach Hills first
solo album astrological streets he's had
the guys from no age and les claypool
on that thing as well but this is AK
he'll second solo LP faced at and with
all honesty I think this is one of the
most original releases of 2010 because
really the only album I can compare this
thing to is Zach Hills first album or a
project that Zach Hill is already
involved in depicted their elements of
rock music in here Noise music punk
music electronica but I would not label
this as any of those not for a second
every song on this album is constantly
shifting
from one idea to another at a pace that
makes it nearly impossible to
concentrate on anything but I'm not
completely sure if I would want to
concentrate on much of this album drum
beats that are completely jarring
production that's extremely harsh and
abrasive synthesizers and loops that
literally burn on the ears and lyrics
that defy interpretation when you stand
back and get far away from these tracks
and maybe listen to them with the volume
low they seem a little gimmicky they
seem a little tacky kind of repetitive
no builds no real transitions no segues
just one section being switched out for
another section being switched out for
another I keep much of these loops these
repetitions don't last longer than just
a couple bars of music but when you get
into the grit of these individual
sections that are being repeated that's
kind of where the magic happens that's
where everything gets really intricate
and intense it's like staring into a
Jackson Pollock painting made of lava
but there are some accessible moments on
here accessible maybe kind of stretching
the word but most of this album honestly
does not sport songs as much as it
sports mutant mind-numbing
noisy motifs my biggest gripe about this
thing is honestly the production it's
mixed extremely extremely messily just
like it was mixed just in a couple
minutes like just throw it together just
throw it together just throw it there if
you can hear it then it must be good
still it's not like that accidentally
happened it's totally intentional it
adds to the harshness of these songs it
adds to the abrasion that face tat
shoots for and yeah I would say that may
be a highlight of this album is the
musicianship hearing Zack Hill on the
drums is quite a treat always always
always but still he's not playing any
more intensely here than he has on his
past releases and Zack Hill is conscious
of the fact that he has a fan base he
knows these people have heard him drum
before so I don't think drooling over
Zack Hills playing style is really the
point of this album I think the point of
this album is to just
overtaking in the noise the psychedelic
sounds just the sensory overload that is
face tak this album is literally the
sound of no restraint whatsoever if
you're enjoying this it's because it's
pushing the envelope it's because it's
tearing at your sensibilities and
overall I would say the name face tat is
extremely fitting for this album though
I may not want one if some dude has one
unless he's looking at me I'm going to
be staring at it I wasn't a huge fan of
this thing and my reasoning is that you
know while I was listening it was
extremely noisy extremely abrasive just
like I said but I just felt empty
afterwards like I had gone through four
years of college and learned absolutely
nothing which is sad I don't want that
feeling but it's what I've received
after listening to this thing multiple
times I'm really like a light five on
this album for all the reasons I just
stated but down there in the comments
let me know what you guys think of this
album did you love it did you hate it
and why and what did you think about
this LP in comparison to Zak Hills last
solo effort Anthony Fantana Zach Hill
face tap for it
you
